de.hshl.obj.loader.objects

Class Mesh

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.hshl.obj.meta.Reflective.DataClass
      • de.hshl.obj.loader.objects.Mesh

  • public final class Mesh
extends Reflective.DataClass
    Contains geometry made of triangles. Stores position, texture coordinates, and normals inside getVertices(). Contains either only vertices, or indexes and reused vertex data. Provides functionality to create Meshes from raw OBJ data.
    Author:
    Johannes Vollmer
    See Also:
    getIndices(), getVertices(), containsNormals(), containsTextureCoordinates()

    • Method Detail

      • merge

        @Nullable
public static Mesh merge(java.util.List<Mesh> meshes,
                                    int vertexSize,
                                    boolean indexing)
        Merge multiple Meshes by concatenating the underlying data arrays. This does not change the geometry of the object, but only the representation.
        Parameters:
        meshes - Parts to be merged
        vertexSize - How many components a single vertex has: Most of the time either 5, 7, or 8.
        indexing - If true, output indexed vertices. Otherwise, getIndices() will be null.
        Returns:
        A single mesh containing the same geometry as all the parts

      • extract

        public static Mesh extract(TriangularOBJBuilder obj,
                           boolean outputIndexed)
        Extract all geometrical data from the TriangularOBJBuilder and put it into a single Mesh.
        Parameters:
        obj - The source OBJ data
        outputIndexed - Whether to output indexed meshes. See Mesh
        Returns:
        A mesh containing the same geometry as the OBJ object

      • extract

        public static Mesh extract(FloatVectors positions,
                           @Nullable
                           FloatVectors textureCoordinates,
                           @Nullable
                           FloatVectors normals,
                           IntegerVectors indices,
                           IndexRange indicesSection,
                           boolean outputIndexed)
        Extract all geometrical data from the TriangularOBJBuilder and put it into a single Mesh.
        Parameters:
        positions - Source position data as in TriangularOBJBuilder.getPositions()
        textureCoordinates - Source texture coordinate data as in TriangularOBJBuilder.getTextureCoordinates()
        normals - Source surface normal data as in TriangularOBJBuilder.getNormals()
        indices - Source index data as in TriangularOBJBuilder.getTriangles()
        indicesSection - Which section of the indices to extract
        outputIndexed - Whether to output indexed meshes. See Mesh
        Returns:
        A mesh containing the geometry

      • getVertices

        public float[] getVertices()
        This array contains all vertex data: position, and optionally texture coordinates and normals, if they were loaded. All vertices are stored in sequence, with each vertex coordinate arranged consecutively.

        There will always be three positional vertices. If neither texture coordinates nor surface normals have been loaded, each vertex will consist of these three coordinates: 
         [ x1, y1, z1,   x2, y2, z2,  ... ]
        X, Y, and Z are the three-dimensional coordinates of the vertex' position.

        If texture coordinates have been loaded, they follow the positional data. Each vertex will consist of five coordinates: 
         [ x1, y1, z1, u1, v1,   x2, y2, z2, u2, v2,  ... ]
        U and V are the two-dimensional coordinates of the vertex' texture coordinate.

        If texture coordinates and surface normals have been loaded, normals are placed at last. Each vertex will consist of eight coordinates: 
         [ x1, y1, z1, u1, v1, a1, b1, c1,   x2, y2, z2, u2, v2, a2, b2, c2,  ... ]
        A, B, and C are the three-dimensional coordinates of the vertex' surface normal.

        If no indices were loaded, the vertices describe the triangular faces, with each consecutive three vertices forming a face. If indices were loaded however, the vertices are not ordered and should be used in conjunction with getIndices().
        See Also:
        containsNormals(), containsTextureCoordinates(), getIndices()

      • containsTextureCoordinates

        public boolean containsTextureCoordinates()
        True, if getVertices() contain texture coordinates.

      • containsNormals

        public boolean containsNormals()
        True, if getVertices() contain normals.

      • getIndices

        @Nullable
public int[] getIndices()
        The triangle faces in this mesh, referencing the data inside getVertices().

        If no indices were loaded, getVertices() describe the triangular faces and this method will return null. If indices were loaded however, the vertices should always be used in conjunction with this index array.
        See Also:
        getVertices()
